bioghist.head: Biographical Sketch
bioghist.p: Sidney Irving Smith (b. 1843, d. 1926) was an important contributor to late 19th century zoological study. As a young man growing up in Norway, Maine, he became an expert on the local fauna and won local praise for his skill as a collector, particularly of insects. Eventually he enrolled at Yale University, where he received formative training under his brother-in-law's tutelage. Following his education, Smith served as assistant in the Sheffield Scientific School and was appointed Professor of Comparative Anatomy at Yale in 1875, a position he maintained until his retirement in 1906.

Relatively early in his career, Smith abandoned his initial focus on insects (he served as State Entomologist in 1872 and 1873) to concentrate on various aspects of the taxonomy and biology of crustaceans, undoubtedly undoubtedly because of his formal association with the U.S. Fish Commission and its coastal survey program. During a career ultimately hindered by health problems, Sidney Smith produced more than 70 papers, many of which have contributed to our basic understanding of the western Atlantic crustacean fauna.

scopecontent.head: Description of the Material
scopecontent.p: These archives are compossed of Sidney I. Smith's correspondence, record books, manuscript and biographical materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Record books relating to Sidney Smith's research.

did.unittitle: Crustacea. Record books relating to Crustacea.
Crustacea. This record book is a listing of C.F.Hartt Expedition of 1870 crustaceans. The list is in Sidney Smith's handwritting as indicated by A.E. Verrill's note on the cover and inside of cover.
Correspondence
Edward Norton Correspondence. Correspondence from E. Norton to S.I. Smith.

Edward Norton Correspondence. A letter from E. Norton informing Smith he has received the box of insects in good condition and will forward them with his own package. (Unknown who the specimens are being forwarded to). See Invoice Ledger.
Edward T. Owen Correspondence. Correspondence from E.T. Owen to S.I. Smith.
Edward T. Owen Correspondence. A letter from E.T. Owen sending Smith an illustration of copulating Prometheus (moth) and concoons of Prometheus.
Edward T. Owen Correspondence. A letter from E.T. Owen informing Smith that his entomology collection will be donated to the museum upon his death.
Ernest Ingersoll Correspondence. Correspondence from E. Ingersoll to S.I. Smith.
Ernest Ingersoll Correspondence. A letter from E. Ingersoll informing Smith he is sending him leeches and mollusks from J.D. Putnam of Davenport, IA for possible identification.
Ezra Townsend Cresson Correspondence. Correspondence from E.T. Cresson to S.I. Smith.

Ezra Townsend Cresson Correspondence. A letter from E.T. Cresson informing Smith he has identified many of the Hymenoptera sent to him. He also disucsses the possibility of exchanges and proposes to name a new species after him, Trogus smithii. See Invoice Ledger
Francis LaBaron Correspondence. Correspondence from F. LeBaron to S.I. Smith.

Francis LaBaron Correspondence. A letter from F. Labaron to S.I. Smith asking him to reconsider his withdrawal and reassuring him that the Woodruff Expedition should leave by October 1st. He Explains Woodruff has lowered to price to ensure enough students.
George W. Peck Correspondence. Corresspondence from G.W Peck to S.I. Smith.
George W. Peck Correspondence. A letter from G.W. Peck asking Smith about the possibility for further exchanges. See Invoice Ledger.
George W. Peck Correspondence. A letter from G.W. Peck including a list of specimens (Insects) sent in exchange. See YPMZ Acc. No. 130. See Invoice Ledger.
George W. Peck Correspondence. A letter from G.W. Peck asking Smith about the possibility of another exchange. See Invoice Ledger.
H.E. Fitz Correspondence. Correspondence from H.E. Fitz to S.I. Smith.
H.E. Fitz Correspondence. A letter from H.E. Fitz sending a crustacea found in a Venus mercenaria to Smith for identification. The specimens were collected in Peconic, Sulllfolk County, NY.
James O. Woodruff Correspondence. Correspondence from J.O. Woodruff to S.I. Smith.
James O. Woodruff Correspondence. A letter from J.O. Woodruff to S.I. Smith inviting him as faculty on his proposed Expedition.
Sidney Irving Smith Correspondence. Outgoing correspondence of S.I. Smith.

Sidney Irving Smith Correspondence. Appears to be a rough copy of an outgoing letter from S.I. Smith, recipient unknown. The letter discusses the sending of Hyale specimens and amphipod taxonomy, including specimens from Kerguelen Islands.

Sidney Irving Smith Correspondence. A 1st draft of a letter from Smith to James Woodruff asking that he be released from any obligation to the Woodruff Expedition and requests Woodruff stop using his name in connection with the Expedition.

Sidney Irving Smith Correspondence. A 1st draft of a letter from Smith to Francis LeBaron, asnwering LeBaron's letter of 24 Jul. He reiterates his position of being released from the Woodruff Expedition and insists his name not be used in connection to the expedition.
Theodore L. Mead Correspondence. Correspondence from T.L. Mead to S.I. Smith.
Theodore L. Mead Correspondence. A letter from T.L Mead asking Smith if he would be interested in an exchange of butterflies. He encloses a list of specimens in his collection from Colorado.
William G. Farlow Correspondence. Correspondence from W.G. Farlow to S.I. Smith regarding the proposed Woodruff Expedition.

William G. Farlow Correspondence. 8 letters from W.G. Farlow to S.I. Smith discussing the proposed Woodruff Expedition. In the letters Farlow expresses concerns with the organizers of the Expedition and problems he is having with said organizers. Subsequently, he decides, along with Smith, to remove their names from consideration based on those concerns.
William Le Baron Jenney Correspondence. Correspondence from W.L.B. Jenney to S.I. Smith.

William Le Baron Jenney Correspondence. A letter from W.L.B. Jenney to S.I. Smith offering his regret that Smith and Farlow would not be joining the Woodruff Expedition, and he will ask that Woodruff keep spots open should they choose to reconsider.
Research Materials
Entomology. Materials relating to S.I. Smith research in Entomology.
Entomology. S.I. Smith notes on Insects, all appear to be from Maine, possibly Expedition of 1864. A note in Verrill's hand reads "S.I. Smith. Norway, ME. Notes on Insects." See Invoice Ledger.
Entomology. A list of Lepidoptera. Appears to be in S.I. Smith's hand. Title says "List of Lepidoptera wanted to complete work." See Invoice Ledger.
